author: Blair Kamin
title: Marina City appears headed toward landmark status
text:
Strong opposition has not materialized against the push to make Marina City an official Chicago landmark, so the iconic riverfront complex is expected to take another step Friday toward permanent protected status, an alderman said.
"I don't see any obstacles," said Ald. Brendan Reilly, 42nd, who initiated the drive for landmarking the pathbreaking 1960s "city within a city" best known for its twin, corncob-shaped towers.
The city's landmarks commission will hold a public hearing on the proposed designation at 9:30 a.m. Friday at City Hall.

(Blair Kamin) Preservationists had expressed concern that the owner of the complex's hotel and commercial spaces, LaSalle Hotel Properties, a Bethesda, Md.-based real estate investment trust, would fight the designation.
But "we haven't heard anything from them," Reilly said.
In addition, the local owners of Marina City's House of Blues music venue have "no objection to the landmarking" even though their corporate parent, concert promoter Live Nation, doesn't want them to formally consent, the alderman said.
Calls to the House of Blues and LaSalle Hotel Properties were not returned.
Bertrand Goldberg and Marina City Chicago History Museum, Hedrich Blessing Archive Architect Bertrand Goldberg, left, with a Marina City model, circa 1960.
Architect Bertrand Goldberg, left, with a Marina City model, circa 1960.
(Chicago History Museum, Hedrich Blessing Archive) The Marina Towers Condo Association, which represents the owners of the complex's nearly 900 apartments, is officially neutral because it previously signed an agreement with the owners of the complex's hotel pledging not to initiate or support landmark status.
But many Marina City residents support landmark designation because it would help upgrade the complex's concrete exterior through the city's "Adopt a Landmark" zoning provision, Reilly said. The measure lets developers build more floor space in return for funding improvements to official city landmarks.
Landmark status would allow the Commission on Chicago Landmarks to regulate changes to the exterior of Marina City, which was designed by architect Bertrand Goldberg and serves as one of the most recognizable forms in the Chicago skyline.
